column2: [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote '''[[Letters not published in "The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien"|a letter]] to [[wikipedia:Iona and Peter Opie|Iona and Peter Opie]]'''.

column1: *'''Publication:''' Excerpts from the letter were published in ''[[The Lore and Language of Schoolchildren]]''. A small excerpt was published in ''[[The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide]]: Chronology''
*'''Background and contents:''' On the occasion of several letters
column3: <ref group="note">''Faynights!'' (also: ''fainits!; fain I!; fains!; fain it!; fainites!''): A shout (often accompanied by crossed fingers) used by UK schoolchildren to call a playground truce. (Source: Tom Dalzell
column6: ''The Concise New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English''.)</ref> having been published in ''Sunday Times''
column7: Iona and Peter Opie sent a letter to the newspaper
column8: explaining the use of the word (published on 25 November 1951). Tolkien read their letter
column9: and wrote a long letter in reply
column10: discussing the etymology of 'faynights'. He wrote that he read their letter "''today
column11: just as I had been puzzling over a curious [[Wikipedia:Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer]] usage''" apparently connected with the issue.<ref>{{CG|RG}}
